provide broadly educational television service for the communities not now
served. In addition, it would permit school districts and State Colleges to
take advantage of two new technical developments in televisions (1) low
power transmitters which can, at minimal expense, provide an instructional
television service throughout a given school district or college campus;
and (2) low power translator television stations which can automatically
receive and retransmit the signals of such established stations as KQED
and KVIE, extending their instructional services into regions not now
reached by their primary signals. A desire to employ both of these services
exists in a large number of school districts and colleges in California today.
2. County school superintendents shall be permitted to use television as an
additional tool in the more effective and economical performance of their
normal functions, using available public funds for such purposes.
a. In-Service training of teachers in new and improved techniques; introÂ¬
duction of new text and study materials; teacher's institutes.
b. Special education programs including speech therapy for children and
parents; teaching the physically handicapped, the gifted child, the
home bound.
c. Special subject teachers in such subjects as foreign languages and
science for districts where such teaching skills are not available.
d. Distribution of films and other audio-visual aids.
The above services, among others, are expensive and frequently cumbersome.
